urn:contentItem:5TVT-7YT1-DXH2-650T-00000-00Media Speculating That President Trump Cancelled His Meeting With Russian President Vladimir Putin Because Michael Cohen Pleaded Guilty; President Trump Said He And Chinese President Xi Jinping Might Have A Deal On Trade; Government Of Tijuana Has Opened Up A New Shelter For Migrants; Trump Administration Plans to Invite Top Executives From German Carmakers To The White House; GM Workers Worried About Announced Layoffs; The Washington Post Reports That User Data Was Used By Facebook For Use By Advertisers; Truck Fleeing Border Patrol Crashes Near Border Killing Three People And Injuring Seven; Media Still Downplays The Crisis In The Southern Border; Mueller's Probe Has No Smoking Gun On Michael Cohen's Plea Deal; Democrats Burying The Trump White House With Subpoenas For The Last Two Years2018-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisEVENING EDIT6:00 PM ESTKurt Schlichter, Kristen Hawn, Liz Peek, Thomas Homan, Bill McGurn, Darrell IssaNEWSFinancial113001cb.233Media Speculating That President Trump Cancelled His Meeting With Russian President Vladimir Putin Because Michael Cohen Pleaded Guilty; President Trump Said He And Chinese President Xi Jinping Might Have A Deal On Trade; Government Of Tijuana Has Opened Up A New Shelter For Migrants; Trump Administration Plans to Invite Top Executives From German Carmakers To The White House; GM Workers Worried About Announced Layoffs; The Washington Post Reports That User Data Was Used By Facebook For Use By Advertisers; Truck Fleeing Border Patrol Crashes Near Border Killing Three People And Injuring Seven; Media Still Downplays The Crisis In The Southern Border; Mueller's Probe Has No Smoking Gun On Michael Cohen's Plea Deal; Democrats Burying The Trump White House With Subpoenas For The Last Two YearsElizabeth MacDonald, Blake Burman, Steve Hilton, Jeff Paul

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I was going to meet with President Putin, but on the basis on what took place with respect to the ships with and the sailors, that was the sole reason.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: We've got lots of breaking details about the G20. We bring you the latest as the media continues to speculate without proof that President Trump canceled his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin not because of Russia's escalating aggression against the Ukraine, but because of the guilty pleas of Michael Cohen.

This as fears rise of a Russian invasion into the Ukraine. Ukraine now banning Russian men age 16 to 60 from the country.

Steve Hilton fired up over that and the misleading reporting he says is coming from the beltway media.

Plus, watch out, Silicon Valley. We've got breaking news on brand-new calls out of Europe for a special counsel like Robert Mueller to get to the bottom of the problems at Facebook and other tech giants once and for all. They got new demands to break them up. We're on it.

To the Democrat battle plan to take down Trump. Did you know that Democrats have already lobby -- lobbed, rather, more than five dozen subpoenas at the president?

Tonight, Republican Congressman Darrell Issa joins me on that. And on James Comey's fight over his hearing before Congress. is Michael Cohen what his guilty is all about, is that the smoking gun against President Trump or not. Even a New York times op-ed and a CNN anchor says they don't see it just yet.

Bill McGurn of the Wall Street Journal joins us with his take and much more.

To tensions at the border. The beltway media criticized for downplaying the crisis. But we've got shocking new numbers about just how lethal those drugs are that are pouring over the border. You won't believe the stunning number.

And to even mayhem at the border. A 100-mile-an-hour car chases with illegals. Chinese illegals coming ashore in a boat on a California beach. We've got former top border patrol Thomas Homan ready to go on that.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You are watching the Fox Business Network.

The Dow closing up nearly 200 points. Its best week since the election. That's ahead of President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping meeting face-to-face possibly over a trade deal tomorrow at the G20 summit. The president signed a trade PAC today at the G20.

Lots of action at the G20. Let's go right to Blake Burman. He is there in Argentina with more. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Liz. And the ebbs and flows with President Trump and China and his position as to whether or not both sides could potentially break this trade's stalemate continue today.

Do you remember yesterday, back at the White House before President Trump got on board Air Force One to come here to the G20 in Buenos Aires, he said he thinks that the United States and China are close on a trade deal, but that he might not necessarily want it because the current situation right now has billions of dollars flowing into the U.S. treasury due to tariffs.

However, once he got here in Argentina today, the president striking much different tone.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We'll be meeting with China as you know, yes, we'll be meeting tomorrow. And we've already spoken. And we are working very hard. If we can make a deal, that will be good. I think they want to and I think we'd like to, and we'll see.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The president's top trade rep, Bob Lighthizer saying today that he has no reason to believe why the dinner meeting between President Trump and President Xi tomorrow night won't be a success. Adding, he thinks at the end of it there will a, quote, "positive feeling."

Still many questions surrounding that potential trade deal. But the president celebrating a victory on a much different one today.

The president beginning his day here in Buenos Aires by signing the USMCA. Standing alongside him Canada's Justin Trudeau and the outgoing Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto. While the president was able to celebrate one of his signature achievements today, there is still much more room for him to go on this one. Back at home at least as Congress will still weigh in on it come 2019, Liz.

MACDONALD: Great to see you, Blake. Good reporting there, sir.

Let's get to the next story. The media without proof saying President Trump avoided Russia's Putin because of the Michael Cohen guilty plea. The administration is again saying today. The real reason is Russian aggression against Ukraine.

Let's bring in Steve Hilton, host of FNC's The Next Revolution. Great to see you, Steve. Thanks for coming on. What's your take--

(CROSSTALK)

STEVE HILTON, FOX NEWS HOST: Hi, Liz.

MACDONALD: What's your take on this?

HILTON: Honestly, Liz, I think this is one of the most laughable examples of Trump derangement syndrome we've ever seen. They've literally gone within 24 hours from saying Trump must stand up to Putin over Ukraine, to then criticizing him for literally doing exactly that.

In a way I think this is helpful. Because it just completely exposes it. It clarifies for everyone that President Trump's critics genuinely don't have any intellectual basis for anything they're saying. They just hate Trump whatever he does at any moment in time has to be wrong.

MACDONALD: You know, Steve, reports do indicate that Russian tanks are just 11 miles on the Ukraine border. Russian naval aggression rising against Ukraine.

Steve, I like your reaction to the Russian captain what he was yelling when his vessel rammed on Sunday on a Ukrainian boat. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: So, Steve, clearly, the intent there we showed in subtitles what the captain was saying. The subtitles in English. Clearly, the intent was there to ram the Ukrainian boat. Isn't that reason enough to cancel the meeting with Putin?

HILTON: Definitely. I mean, that was really frightening to hear that, that roar moment there. Clearly, an aggressive posture. And I think the president was exactly right to cancel the meeting, by the way, as all President Trump's critics were asking that will be a proportionate measure.

But I think the long-term the real story here is standing up to President Putin's aggression generally, which of course the Obama administration totally failed to do. Did absolutely nothing when Putin walked into Crimea and then Ukraine and subsequently. Whereas, the Trump administration is being tough on Russia. We've already seen that with sanctions applied much more rigorously and extensively than anything we saw in the Obama administration.

And then also, the key one is energy. Because Putin's whole regime is dependent on energy. And what President Trump has done here to unleash American energy production is really the key to taking away Putin's power to just wander around the world doing whatever he wants his energy that his regime depends on.

MACDONALD: You know, and Russia, to your point, Steve, could really stick it to Europe. And you know, just turning up the spigot at wheel into Europe of fuel there. And Steve, your take on Germany now silent on Russia sticking it to the Ukraine, because Russia's Nord Stream 2 gas pipe, the gas pipeline deal with Germany means Russia can circumvent the Ukraine. Go ahead, Steve.

HILTON: Yes, it's an outrageous situation. That pipeline is a total outrage. Remember, the chairman of the company that's putting that, that put that deal together is Gerhard Schroeder, the former German chancellor, Angela Merkel's predecessor is completely corrupt, is completely outrageous.

President Trump again was right to raise that. Do you remember that NATO summit when he really let the NATO secretary-general have it in relation to that pipeline, because that is a real security issue. The best thing that we can do is to take the country out of the orbit of Russian dependence on energy and actually have them buy American energy instead. That will be good all around.

MACDONALD: Steve, it seems like, you know, analysts, some analyst, top analysts are saying it might be better for the U.S. to stay silent and just quietly use power with regards to what Russia is doing with Ukraine.

Some are pointing what China does. China doesn't ram boats or buzz aircraft carriers in the South China -- in the South China Sea. Instead, it slowly turns reefs into islands and then fortifies them into airbases.

HILTON: Yes. But I think that, you know, we're not -- we're not authoritarian regimes, and so we do things differently. And the important point is to stand up to that kind of adventurism internationally. And again, this administration is doing that much more than we've seen before, especially in relation to China, where action is.

President Trump has overturn decades of basically sucking up to China and letting them get away with anything that they want. He's really standing up to them, and I think we need to see more about of that, both for China and for Russia because that's the language that they understand. The real pressure.

MACDONALD: You could see the tone is totally different at the G20, you know, the world leaders are really on their toes right now, Steve. Final word.

HILTON: Yes. Look, I think that there is a good instinct there to try and make a deal, but I think that what the president, our present needs to do is really keep up the pressure on China. He's got them in the right place, whether for the first time in many, many years. They're really worried about what America is going to do. I would say keep the pressure on because there's a lot more to do to make that trade relationship fare.

MACDONALD: Steve Hilton, great to see you, sir. Thanks so much for coming in. And you can catch Steve's show, the Next Revolution Sundays at 9 p.m. on the Fox -- on the Fox News Network.

With me now, let's bring in the political power panel. It's conservative commentator Kurt Schlichter and Democrat strategist Kristen Hawn. Great to see you both.

KRISTEN HAWN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Hi.

KURT SCHLICHTER, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Great to be here.

MACDONALD: What's your -- first to you, Kurt, what's your take into the media beltway and their reporting, saying that because Michael Cohen reached out, reportedly to and allegedly to somebody in the Kremlin that that's why the president canceled his meeting with Vladimir Putin.

SCHLICHTER: Yes. I'll tell how this revelation is that Michael Cohen I had to go on Google to find the guy's address to send it to him because they were just like that. It's so ridiculous, you know.

I got to say, Liz, though, I'm really glad about these Russiaphobes come lately, because when I was literally in the Cold War in West Germany across from the Russians and they want to kill us. I remember all my liberal friends were telling me that, you know, you're crazy. You're not sure about your warmongering lunatics.

But now, now, we have realized that Russia is bad. And I'm really glad that they come to the party 35 years late.

MACDONALD: Kristen, what's your take?

HAWN: Well, I mean, I think that, you know, we're finally holding Russia the task. I think Steve was right. Putin response to strength and power. The President didn't show that before, but I think that we're making progress there. And back talking about, you know, the issue of energy dependence in Europe, depending on Russia for, you know, natural gas.

It's a really dangerous circumstance that is happening right now over in Western Europe, so. You know, I think that that we have to show power. We, through the Congress and through the president and we're doing that.

MACDONALD: And to Kristen's point about fuel, it is at the heart of this geopolitical fighting, right, Kurt? And you know, in fact, our oil patch has rescued us from a potential recession right after the 2008 a crisis. The oil patch is really firing on all cylinders, Kurt. The Permian basin they're giving away natural gas for free.

SCHLICHTER: You know, Liz, I'm so tired of the European elite refusing to do its share. Look, building this pipeline to bypass the Ukraine so they can import more Russian fossil fuels when we have them to sell is insane. It is a strategic disaster because now they're on Putin's leash. (Inaudible) belong to him, plus, they're shafting their ally.

(CROSSTALK)

HAWN: Yes. I would -- I would point out--

SCHLICHTER: The people who guarded him for 30 years.

MACDONALD: Yes. Go--

(CROSSTALK)

HAWN: I would point out--

SCHLICHTER: Through the 70's.

MACDONALD: Yes, go ahead, Kristen.

HAWN: Yes. I would just point out that I was talking to few friends in the Senate earlier today and they pointed out to me that we have actually hit an all-time high of exports of crude oil to Western Europe. So, you know, this is something that they are paying attention over there.

MACDONALD: Go ahead, Kurt.

SCHLICHTER: We should sell it all to them. They should buy nothing from Russia. Every dollar they give to Putin is another dollar for armaments to go kill Ukrainians to threaten Polls, to threaten Estonians, Lithuanians and Latvians--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Syrians.

SCHLICHTER: -- our allies.

MACDONALD: Yes.

SCHLICHTER: Exactly. That's not oil. That's blood.

MACDONALD: Yes, go ahead, take that point on, Kristen.

HAWN: Well, I would agree with that. I think this is a partisan issue at all. I think Russia is, you're exactly right, is threat to the rest of the world and not just to us, but to Western Europe, to Ukraine. And so, you know, I agree.

MACDONALD: And Kurt, Russia is in trouble. It's in recessionary mode, so as China. There's more saber rattling coming out of those countries when they're, you know, back down on the mat, right?

SCHLICHTER: Yes, but it's foolish saber rattling. Look, we don't want to be opposed to Russia in the way that we were during the entire Cold War. Again, I personally served in it. I remember it. And we don't want that. We were excited when the wall fell.

MACDONALD: OK.

SCHLICHTER: That there was hope that they could join the nations and become prosperous and become peaceful part of the community. That's really our goal. But if they're looking for a fight. Hey, here we are, Vladimir. Let's rock.

MACDONALD: OK. Thanks. You're going to be back later in the show, you guys. Great stuff there.

To new developments at the border. U.S. officials now say troops there will be cut to 4,000, eventually, from 5600.

Jeff Paul is on the ground in Tijuana with the latest. Jeff?

JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Elizabeth, we're here at the newest shelter to open up in Tijuana that's housing many of those migrants who have traveled from Central America. And as we get through the gate here you could see a big part of the reason why they have opened up this shelter now, is because of all the space here compared to the old shelter.

There's also much more covered space compared to the old shelter which is been a big issue with the heavy rains that have fallen over the last few days. It's created mud. And with so many people living in such a tight space health has become a concern as well.

We spoke to one of the migrants who has moved from the old shelter to the new one about that new facility, here's what he had to say. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: People asking, people crying. A little kid, woman, and like old people crying for when it's raining. Nothing to wear. No water. No bathrooms. Nothing like that, you know what I mean. That's why we called to a government agency who can help with this people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL: The local Tijuana government has also moved much of the resources that they provided to the migrants at the old shelter to the new shelter like food. We'll see how many migrants are enticed to move to the new location because of that, or how many decide just to give up on the dream of entering the United States and just decide to return home to Central America. Elizabeth?

MACDONALD: Great to see you, sir. Great reporting there, Jeff.

In other headlines, the FBI now investigating the hotel chain Marriott after it suffered the second worst cyber-attack in the last 10 years. Some 500 million guest records potentially hacked, that's more than the population of the U.S. and Russia combined. Passport numbers, e-mail addresses, and more. Marriott is trying to grow around the world.

Now a growing number of senators and state attorneys general demanding answers to Alaska. A massive 7.0 earthquake today, caused widespread damage across anchorage. Many roads and bridges knocked out power. More than 100 schools canceled classes.

And new developments on that deadly Lion Air crashed off of Indonesia that killed 189 people in October. Boeing software blamed for the crash. Reports that Boeing now considering upgrading that problematic software for its 737, the 737 Max planes in about 68 weeks.

Coming up, more breaking details on new calls out of the E.U. to appoint a Robert Mueller-type special prosecutor to get to the bottom of user abuses at Facebook and Google.

Plus, a brand-new conservative censorship scandal at Google. We're going to debate it. And G.M. Motors, General Motors, the workers there in Lordstown, Ohio publicly praying for each other after the car company announced 14,000 layoffs. More on that story coming up next. Stay there.

MACDONALD: Welcome back. The Trump administration now finishing plans to invite top executives from German carmakers, Volkswagen, BMW and Daimler to the White House next week. Big push by the president to get jobs here in the U.S.

This, as G.M. workers are seeing publicly praying after G.M. announced more than 14,000 layoffs at factories in the U.S. There's a big waterfall effect here.

Now, last night on this show, we had on the mayor of Lordstown, Ohio. He said every job loss at that G.M. factory there causes numerous other jobs to be lost at businesses elsewhere in the area that are depend on the factory.

One estimate says it's as high as seven jobs like at other places that could be lost.

Let's bring in expert analysis from one of the best Fox News contributors and writers all around, columnist with The Hill, Liz Peek. Great to see you, Liz.

LIZ PEEK, COLUMNIST, FISCAL TIMES: Thank you. Glad to be here.

MACDONALD: That's all the jobs.

PEEK: Yes, it is. And that's of course why Obama and everybody else wanted to save General Motors and save for during the financial crisis. It wasn't just those jobs that were apparel the entire industry and all their suppliers and the people living in those communities. Everybody was in jeopardy.

But, you know, the one good thing to think about, as compared to that era, right now, there are a million more jobs available than there are workers just to fill them. There is such an ebullient jobs market, even in manufacturing skills. There are lots of people out there--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: That's a great point.

PEEK: -- and there are a lot of manufacturing jobs. We've added 300,000 jobs over the last -- in manufacturing over the last two years. So, this is, I am really unhappy as President Trump is about what General Motors is doing, particularly because it was really their problem. I mean, they basically guessed wrong on the kinds of cars that Americans are going to want.

Everybody bought into the idea that our prices were never coming down again.

MACDONALD: Right.

PEEK: It just never happens. Oil price going down.

MACDONALD: Right.

PEEK: I mean, I can sign an affidavit, it would make any difference. But guess what.

MACDONALD: Yes. I know. You wonder why--

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: That's how it happens.

MACDONALD: You wonder why they can't fill factories that can be retooled when oil prices go up and down.

PEEK: Well, I think they're overstocked in general.

MACDONALD: Yes.

PEEK: We just really are not seeing a big growing auto market. so.

MACDONALD: Yes. There is a flattening--

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: That's exactly right.

MACDONALD: -- with the (Inaudible) in the U.S. sales. But you know what's really interesting is now we have Ohio Congressman Tim Ryan visibly upset. He is basically shooting an arrow across the bow, saying Washington doesn't care about middle America. He is saying venture capital the coastal elites only care about their neck of the woods, about California and New York.

But he is saying that Washington is continuing to ignore the Midwest. He doesn't say Trump is, he is saying D.C.

PEEK: Well, I think that's what elected President Trump.

MACDONALD: Yes.

PEEK: Is that basically people were ignoring the rustbelt, it's called the rustbelt for a reason. It was in many years in decline. We lost millions of jobs and no one said a word.

MACDONALD: To China.

PEEK: Well, to China.

MACDONALD: And elsewhere.

PEEK: To Mexico, all over the place. And so, hostility towards these trade agreements, hostility towards other people taking our jobs is not new and it is not misbegotten. I mean, there is a reason why this is all happening.

Now, look, Trump has actually set the stage for revival in manufacturing in this country, and there are many reasons to think that we are competitive. We have low energy cost and energy through our lifetimes is not going to change. That's a big change. For example, our difference between us, and for example, Germany. Germany doesn't have because of their I think incredibly stupid energy policies.

But we have energy. We have the major consumer market is still in the world here. It's not China. We're still a bigger consumer market. We had English speaking labor. We had all kinds of advantages. So, the pessimism of the Obama years was, I think totally wrong. I think we can do this.

And by the way, some of these European automakers are talking about expanding here. And I think given proper incentives and so forth they will do that.

MACDONALD: You know, the president is having the foreign carmakers here next week.

PEEK: Yes.

MACDONALD: To your point about President Obama, he said, how is President Trump going to do that.

PEEK: Magic wand.

MACDONALD: With magic wand.

PEEK: I know. It's such a snooty kind of comment, but he didn't know anything about private industry. He had never been involved in it. None of his advisers had ever been in manufacturing.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: He was talking about -- he was, President is talking about manufacturing think tanks and institutes, he does think it fix it, right.

PEEK: Yes. Right, which is a very different kind of situation. Look.

MACDONALD: It's like the teacher's faculty lounge answered, too.

PEEK: That's exactly right. If you lower taxes that were competitive, and we were not historically, we have the highest tax rate for our corporations of all the developed countries, and you basically get back some of this environmental regulation mainly. You know what, you can compete here. And I think that's the big take away.

MACDONALD: Liz Peek, we love having you on. And read Liz Peek's column, she's a terrific writer with great analysis.

PEEK: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Liz Peek.

PEEK: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Have a good weekend.

PEEK: You, too.

MACDONALD: Now you won't believe the numbers we are seeing about the new reports of the massive amount of illegal drugs seized at the border this year and last year. The Fentanyl seize, wait for it, enough to kill 78 million people. Yes, 78 million people. We are going to discuss whether the beltway media downplaying the danger at our footstep -- at our doorstep is so bad for the country.

Former ICE acting director Tom Homan is here. He is s ready to go on that one. But first, a bombshell report. The Washington Post reporting that Facebook was using your data as a bargaining chip in exchange to get companies to buy advertising. We got the details coming up. Stay there.

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, THE EVENING EDIT HOST, FOX BUSINESS: Now to the bombshell report about Facebook. The "Washington Post" reporting that new Facebook internal e-mails had surfaced indicate that Facebook doled out (ph) access to your user data in exchange for advertising buys, using user data as a bargaining chip.

Companies cited include Lyft, Tinder, Amazon and Airbnb. This, as calls grow in Europe for a new Robert Mueller type special prosecutor to go after Facebook and other big tech companies. This is the former prime minister of Belgium. He's an E.U. official. He's saying, "Facebook's monopoly control over millions of people's personal data and the flow of news and information online pose a clear and present threat to democracy.

He also says that Facebook's management has shown time and again it cannot be trusted to behave responsibly. This official also pointing out that Facebook has failed to still deliver a comprehensive internal audit about what exactly happened with the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

Remember, Cambridge Analytica was reading Facebook messages and compared the Facebook issues to the 2008 banking crisis. He's saying, "Banks then, they didn't regulate themselves. Techs sure is not. We got to step in. Kurt Schlichter and Kristen Hawn are back. Kurt, wow! A Robert Mueller type special prosecutor to investigate Facebook and Silicon Valley? What do you think?

KURT SCHLICHTER, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Well, since I don't think much of Robert Mueller, I don't think much of that idea, but I do think that the tech monopolies because that's what they are, aren't really capitalism in the way that we know it. What they are doing is they are not only playing with our data, they are trying to control the flow of information.

And the simple fact is, no capitalist ideology that I'm familiar with requires us to submit to a bunch of bay area liberals deciding what we can and can't say. Something's got to be done. They haven't done it. I'm willing to look at some options. And they brought it on themselves.

MACDONALD: You know, Kristen, for Facebook, you know, for all the data the scandals, right, are they sincerely sorry that they got caught?

KRISTEN HAWN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I think that's the situation we're looking at. I mean, this is a situation where -- and I agree with my counterpart on the right -- there something that has to be done. I'm not sure about a special prosecutor, but there's clearly a role for Congress to act in a bipartisan way to regulate because Facebook isn't self-regulating.

The issue though comes down, you know, the devil is always in the details. So, do you regulate Facebook as a financial institution? Do you regulate it as a news organization? There are a lot of questions that need to be answered, you know, and I think that they began to ask those questions when they brought Zuckerberg

MACDONALD: Well, they are exempt -- yes, they are exempt from lawsuits because they say they publish political discourse.

HAWN: Right.

MACDONALD: You know, the issue too, Kurt, is that Facebook says it did not sell your data. It did sell -- it looks like it may have sold access to the data so it's playing fast and loose there. And the entire app industry is built on the backs of Facebook user data and Google data. And then we also had, you know, Sheryl Sandberg asking Facebook workers, Kurt, to do opposition research on George Soros after Soros said Facebook is a menace. I mean, how deeply involved was Sandberg?

SCHLICHTER: You know, probably pretty deeply. Look, I'm no fan of George Soros and Facebook can go and do whatever politicking it wants, but you know what, so can we. And the simple fact is, Facebook and Twitter and all the rest of these tech giants have taken an outside role in our politics. I would not be as concerned if they were not monopolies, but they transparently are. And we have to do something about it.

We have got to maintain a system where every American can participate in the debate. And from the bannings on Twitter and Facebook and everything, we see that a bunch of hipsters in San Jose, California are trying to decide what can and can't be said over the internet. And that's unacceptable, meaning we won't accept it.

MACDONALD: I'm sorry to jump in because we do have breaking news now, Kristen, and Google, there is new reports that again, Google, based on internal e-mails, Google workers again debated burying, pushing down conservative media in searches -- in the searches on the search engine, with the goal of impacting future election, Kristen, that's a bombshell.

HAWN: Yes, I mean, whether it's Russia, whether it's, you know, and this isn't in my mind a political issue. I mean, there are people on the left that are doing it. There are people on the right that are doing it. And there are certainly foreign governments that are trying to impact our elections.

MACDONALD: Yes, but time and again, Kristen, we do see conservative voices suppressed on Facebook and Google. That's a fact. I have seen it. I have seen the reports.

HAWN: Well, I mean, and at the end of the day, it's all across the board on the right and left, it is unacceptable. And, you know, it is very clear that they can't police themselves. We need to step in.

MACDONALD: Kurt and Kristen, you have been great. Thank you so much. And say hi to Bitey (ph) and Barky (ph), Kurt, you have a new dog, Barkey (ph).

SCHLICHTER: We do. He's horrendous. He's a terrible dog.

MACDONALD: Love it. More terrible the better. Coming up -- great to see you guys -- coming up next, the beltway media down playing the border crisis in the face of staggering new data about lethal drugs including fentanyl pouring in. Mayhem, like fatal car chases with illegals, and more. And we're going to talk to former ICE acting director Thomas Homan about that, next.

And later in the show, we are looking at the facts, just the facts and nothing but the facts, in the news about Michael Cohen and the Mueller probe with Bill McGurn of the "Wall Street Journal." Stay there.

MACDONALD: The media continues to down play the criminal problems at the border. Look at this. New government data show that the amount of illegal fentanyl seized this year and last could kill about 78 million people. Yes, 78 million people. You just need 2 milligrams -- 2 milligrams of fentanyl to kill somebody.

There's even more mayhem at the border. Feds also just arresting 39 smugglers and another major $2.7 million drug bust involving crystal meth. And separately from that, three killed and seven hurt. Authorities have not said if they are illegals. Here's what happened.

A truck hit speeds of 100 miles-per-hour in a chase at the border with Border Patrol. It's believed that there was a smuggler, a human trafficking smuggler at the car. And there is this story. Another nine illegals came ashore at Laguna Beach California, a number of them from China. So, why are so many in the beltway media down playing the border chaos?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIPS)

JONATHAN LEMIRE, WHITE HOUSE REPORTER, ASSOCIATED PRESS: -- well he has steadily escalated the rhetoric on this. So whether or not he created the crisis, he certainly heightened it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is not a caravan of stone cold criminals. These are families.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I as a national security official would want to focus on the actual threats and not these inventive threats of caravans that they are thousands miles away.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's not who is in that caravan by in large, and we all know that. And as long as President Trump insists on perpetuating those myths, insists on doing that, we're not going to reach a political solution.

(END VIDEO CLIPS)

MACDONALD: Let's take it up with former ICE acting director Thomas Homan. Great to see you, sir.

THOMAS HOMAN, FORMER ICE ACTING DIRECTOR: Good to see you.

MACDONALD: OK, it is almost like they are talking to each other, standing on the same corner and not out there trying to get to the story, into the bottom of it. First, the fentanyl, enough fentanyl to kill 78 million people seized at the border this year and last. Again, just 2 milligrams can kill you, way more potent than heroin. Are we in the media not giving this enough coverage?

HOMAN: Well, you know, I think there's a lot of coverage, but the left, the liberals, the progressive, they don't want to talk about it because look, the smuggling of fentanyl in which you are right, is very powerful but it is also very cheap, a lot cheaper than heroine and cocaine.

So, they don't want to talk about it because drug smuggling goes hand in hand with alien smuggling. They use similar pathways. They use -- the southern border is a way to get through. And so when you talk about illegal immigration, you can't leave out drug smuggling. They go hand in hand.

The same organization who smuggle aliens, many of them smuggle drugs. So it comes hand in hand. And they don't want to talk about it because that's border security or border control, which they don't want.

MACDONALD: So, you know, let's get to the car crashes happening along certain routes out of the border. What's the detail on that? I think you said in talking to us, that it only takes upwards of five minutes to get from the boarder to a major highway?

HOMAN: Yes, that crash happened in Boulevard, California. I was actually a Border Patrol agent in Boulevard, so I patrolled those roads for years. And when that accident occurred, that's really close to the border. Matter of fact, me and my partner seized 1,200 pounds of cocaine in that very similar area.

It takes between three and six minutes to get from that border to Interstate 8. And once they get to the interstate, of course they get lost in the interstate traffic. So luckily, way back then, we actually saw the vehicle before entering the interstate. But yes, within five minutes you can be from the Mexican border on a major interstate and get lost during an interstate traffic.

MACDONALD: All right. So, what is your take on nationals from China -- Chinese nationals, illegals coming ashore at Laguna Beach?

HOAMAN: When I was director of ICE, we removed people to almost 140 different countries. The Border Patrol arrests people from over 100 countries every year. Chinese usually come through Canada, but you see more and more of the Chinese are coming through the southern border.

And since there's a lot of attention right now on the southern border with DOD down there along with extra Border Patrol assets, they are trying to find ways around it, which I said weeks ago was a great plan by the president because now he sent DOD down there, the cartels are going crazy because they can't move their product as freely as they could.

Because they move a group of aliens in one sector, keep the Border Patrol busy, and move narcotics and bad people through another sector. And the DOD down there is shutting that down pretty well so now they're going through a water way (ph).

MACDONALD: That's the breaking news. Tom Homan, we want to have you back on the show next week about how the Pentagon officials -- excuse me -- troops at the border are shutting down the drug cartels. Great stuff, Tom Homan, and thank you so much for your service to our country. Come back soon.

HOMAN: You got it.

MACDONALD: We want you next week, actually. Coming up, Democrats firing off subpoena cannon at Trump. But you know, more than five dozen subpoenas were aimed at Trump so far this year from the Democrats. But will all of this backfire? We're bringing on Republican Congressman Daryl Issa to take it on.

But first, more and more media host on the left and the right asking just where is that smoking gun against Trump in the Michael Cohen guilty plea? CNN asking that. The "New York Times" asking that. We're going to take it up with Bill McGurn of the "Wall Street Journal," next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST: This is clearly not welcome news for the president. I don't want to pretend that it is. But once again, I look at these documents and I don't see any evidence of conspiracy between members of the Trump team and members of the Russian government to interfere in the election.

REP. JERRY NADLER (D), NEW YORK: The fact that it was negotiating with a foreign power or business deals while you are running for president --

TAPPER: Not illegal. You mean, like more just cloak (ph) really.

NADLER: Yes, yes, yes.

TAPPER: But still no conspiracy?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: No conspiracy. That's Jake Tapper of CNN saying that. Let's get right to Bill McGurn of the "Wall Street Journal" over the Robert Mueller probe. I mean, so the "New York Times" is also saying the same thing of what JAKE TAPPER SAID. Your take?

BILL MCGURN, CHIEF EDITORIAL WRITER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: My take is I never thought I would be saying to you I agree with Jake Tapper, but there's no evidence of what the charge was. And look, I think special counsel -- I think special counsel's corrupt, independent counsel's corrupt, absolutely, it is a bad idea. It is extra constitutional.

They are supposed to be even -- if you take it seriously, it is supposed to be investigating a crime. This one was set up as a counterintelligence effort to investigate what Russia did in the election and whether the Trump organization or Trump people were complicit in that, conspired to alter the election. No evidence of that, all these months into it.

It looks to me like what the special counsel is doing is trying to put together this narrative of here's these things Trump did and maybe didn't come clean about them later, but not illegal. But is that really what a special counsel -- should we have these extra constitutional people hovering around the edges with all this power and being in fact an opposition power? I don't think so.

MACDONALD: Well, they are saying that, you know, Trump wasn't forthcoming about his business dealings with the tower in Moscow.

MCGURN: Yes. I'm not sure. First of all, he didn't have a business deal, right? It didn't go through.

MACDONALD: There was no guarantee.

MCGURN: It didn't go through, right? And second, I believe Donald Trump, Jr. in his testimony, talked about looking at investments from 2015 and 2016 as well. So there is really not a lot of new there.

MACDONALD: But we've been 19 months into this, and the D.C. media beltway is absolutely unhinged.

MCGURN: Of course. Right.

MACDONALD: And the poison coming out of it. Sorry, I watch it. It is poison. And they're not reporting -- you know, I talk to people, oh, Boeing had a problem with software in an airplane? Really? Facebook is having a problem? They are only watching MSNBC or CNN. It is unbelievable what's going on.

MCGURN: Right. No, it is, and it's just -- look, I think you can think that the special counsel's provisions is corrupting to politics without believing that the special counsel himself, Bob Mueller, is personally corrupt.

MACDONALD: Understood, yes.

MCGURN: It just leads to this because it doesn't seem to be in anyone's interest to say I've looked into this, and I haven't found what I was charged with finding.

MACDONALD: They are going to now try to link Roger Stone with WikiLeaks and then to Trump --

MCGURN: Yes. And all these -- as Michael Cohen, OK --

MACDONALD: And then Trump will be talking about Hillary's health.

MCGURN: Right. And we have learned Michael Cohen is not a very honest guy and he's got a lot of legal problems that again didn't really have anything to do with collaboration between the Trump administration and the government of Russia to effect the outcome of the elections, right?

MACDONALD: It's well -- will you come back on --

MCGURN: Yes.

MACDONALD: I mean, when do you think Mueller is going to come forward with --

MCGURN: I don't know. I mean, I have thought with the questions to the president that that's kind of what you do near the end, but there's no sign of the end and that's one of the problems.

MACDONALD: Bill McGurn, we need you on the story. Will you come back?

MCGURN: Yes, I will.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, sir.

MCGURN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We're going to be right back. Stay right there. Darrell Issa next.

MACDONALD: Well, it looks like the Democrat game plan moving forward is simply to try and bury the Trump White House in subpoenas. In fact, the Democrats have fired off 64 subpoenas since 2016 on a range of issues, from election meddling to conflicts of interests, to the border, to the census and more. With us now is Republican congressman, Darrell Issa, of California. Great to see you, sir.

REP. DARREL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: Great to be on Liz and it will be interesting to see if they can exceed in a month what any Republican ever did in a year in the way of subpoenas.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. I wanted to say first congratulations on your nomination to run the U.S. Trade and Development Agency. Good to see that sir.

ISSA: Well, I'd be glad to be getting back into working with business. I sort of missed it during my time in Congress.

MACDONALD: OK, so five dozen subpoenas, more than that filed against the White House. Your take on that?

ISSA: Well, I think they are playing into their own election narrative. In the election, they basically said Trump has done all these things wrong and we're going to prove it by getting the documents. I think what they're going to be surprised is after an extensive period of time, great cost to the government.

What they are going to come up with is similar to what you had in the last segment where Mueller is still almost two years into investigating and is still looking for the crime that was alleged.

MACDONALD: Yes. We also have breaking news story, judge may rule on Monday on whether James Comey can testify in public or behind closed doors. James Comey wants a public hearing. He says he is afraid of leaks. Your take on that.

ISSA: Well, there are plenty of ways to prevent leaks, but one of the ways to prevent leaks is for Comey not to be a leaker, which is, you know, he has selected been a leaker at a lot of times. The other thing is that he had an assurance by Chairman Goodlatte that the entire interview would be recorded and would be then made available so it wouldn't be about leaks.

It would be about having the off air hour per side type of deposition, that quite frankly, Comey has grown up on. Depositions are not done in five- minute sound bites the way public hearings are and Comey knows that.

MACDONALD: So there is nothing wrong with a behind-doors hearing, right? And then you can have the transcript released, right sir? Is that what you're saying?

ISSA: Exactly. And just because I have worked with him before, if we were in a public hearing and we asked questions about FISA, the first thing he would say is I'm sorry I can't answer in this venue. So, to a certain extent, he would like to be out in the open where the situations related to wrongdoing in a FISA warrant would by definition, be things he would no answer.

So, the other part of it is, that the closed door is where when he's asked a question, he says well it's classified, you say great, let's make sure we only have people with clearances in the room and now please answer. He would like to circumvent that and get out of town as the Republicans leave control of the House.

MACDONALD: What's the one thing that bothers you about James Comey in this entire affair?

ISSA: I guess what bothers me is that you want to have a higher opinion of the integrity of the office than a number of things that he has done, some of even before recently. You might remember when he claimed that he couldn't crack the Apple phone and he had to get Apple to give him a code- breaking software. Later proven not to be something he needed.

The fact that you see somebody who you relied on for the absolute most important law enforcement agency who obviously plays fast and loose with what he says and does. And that's a disappointment and it does make you worry about whether you can trust the new management of the FBI, the next management of the FBI. That is something the American people rely on.

MACDONALD: Congressman Darrell Issa, good to see you sir. Thank you so much for coming in.

ISSA: Thanks Liz.

MACDONALD: And thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good weekend.

value.Title: Medical board issues warning to doctors; After local doctor touted hydroxychloroquine, agency warns against talk of COVID-19 cures
value.Overview: The Houston Chronicle, A; Pg. A003, 698words

Extracts.SummaryText: ... regulates the practice of medicine has advised physicians it can take action against those who promise a cure for COVID-19. The Texas Medical Board issued a statement about such claims Friday, just a few days after Immanuel, a Houston pastor-doctor, very publicly touted hydroxychloroquine as a cure for the disease. Numerous studies have found the drug does not show any benefit against COVID-19 and the Food and Drug Administration has cautioned about its use because of reports ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60HH-PW01-DYRV-424J-00000-00Medical board issues warning to doctors; After local doctor touted hydroxychloroquine, agency warns against talk of COVID-19 cures2020-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisAPg. A003Medical board issues warning to doctors; After local doctor touted hydroxychloroquine, agency warns against talk of COVID-19 curesTodd Ackerman

In an apparent warning shot at Dr. Stella Immanuel, the Texas agency that regulates the practice of medicine has advised physicians it can take action against those who promise a cure for COVID-19.

The Texas Medical Board issued a statement about such claims Friday, just a few days after Immanuel, a Houston pastor-doctor, very publicly touted hydroxychloroquine as a cure for the disease. Numerous studies have found the drug does not show any benefit against COVID-19 and the Food and Drug Administration has cautioned about its use because of reports linking it with heart problems and other injuries and disorders.

"A physician must provide full disclosure of treatment options, side effects, obtain informed consent, and there cannot be false, misleading or deceptive advertising or statements made regarding any therapies, including a cure for COVID-19," says the medical board's statement.

The statement said if the board were to receive a complaint for false, misleading or deceptive advertising, it would be reviewed following its standard enforcement process. It did not say the complaint had to involve harm to a patient.

The statement represented an unusually quick response by a state medical board to a public event. Immanuel was not specifically mentioned, but the statement noted "a widely published claim of a 'cure' for COVID-19" in the past week.

In a video that went viral early last week, Immanuel called it "fake science" to say hydroxychloroquine doesn't work and said "if they put everybody on hydroxychloroquine . it would stop covid in its tracks in 30 days." She reposted her video Tuesday on her Twitter page, writing that "Big Tech is censoring Experts and suppressing the CURE. I will not be silenced."

She told the Chronicle on Thursday she has used the drug on more than 400 people, including the elderly, asthmatics and diabetics, and "we have not lost a patient yet."

The video, taken at a press conference Immanuel led on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court, was shared on Twitter by President Donald Trump. The video was later removed for sharing false information by Twitter as well as Facebook and YouTube, where it was also posted.

The Texas Medical Board statement, noting the medical community is "still learning, researching and gaining understanding of the virus," said that while drugs and therapies are being used to treat COVID-19, "there is no definitive cure at this time." It said any treatment decision must be made "with full, proper and accurate disclosure by a physician."

The Texas Medical Board licensed Immanuel in November 2019 for pediatrics and emergency medicine with an address associated with the Rehoboth Medical Center. She has no documented disciplinary actions or known complaints in Texas or Louisiana, where she was first licensed in 1998.

Immanuel was sued for medical malpractice in Louisiana in January in a case involving a woman who died in 2019 after being treated by Immanuel, according to court filings.

Immanuel and another doctor prescribed medication to a woman who complained of a broken needle in her arm after doing methamphetamine, but the family alleged she did not order a closer look at her area through an X-ray or other medical tests. The woman later developed a flesh-eating disease from the wound and died, according to documents provided by the family's lawyer.

Immanuel is not the only Houston doctor to use the drug. Dr. Robin Armstrong , medical director of a Texas City nursing home and a state GOP officer, provided the drug to 35 residents who had tested positive but not yet shown symptoms after an outbreak there. And the drug is part of a cocktail that Dr. Joseph Varon , chief of staff at United Memorial Medical Center, has touted as working "like a charm" there.

It is unclear if Armstrong and Varon are still providing the drug.

todd.ackerman@chron.com

urn:contentItem:5S59-3FH1-F021-63WV-00000-00Medical research needs big data - Tessa Jowell gets the ball rolling;We think nothing of sharing personal information with tech giants so why are we so suspicious about our health records?2018-04-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisOPINIONVersion:1Medical research needs big data - Tessa Jowell gets the ball rollingWe think nothing of sharing personal information with tech giants so why are we so suspicious about our health records?Sonia Sodha

Half of us born after 1960 will be told we have cancer at some point in our lives. Virtually no one will go through life untouched by the disease, whether as a sufferer, a survivor or supporter. So every year, millions of us lace up running shoes, bake cakes and cultivate moustaches in memory of loved ones to raise the cash needed for cancer research.

But money is not the only critical ingredient in developing new cures. An important constraint on the pace of progress is the lack of large datasets that contain valuable information on how patients are responding to different types of treatment.

So it is hugely significant that Tessa Jowell has pledged to make a different sort of donation to cancer research. The former culture secretary has won plaudits for her bravery in speaking out about her experience of suffering from an aggressive brain tumour and her calls for greater collaboration in the fight against cancer. She has now announced she will become the first person to donate her health records to a new global cancer database being set up by an Australian philanthropist. Cancer researchers have hailed it a   gamechanger : it will enable them to look at what people responding well to particular cancer treatments have in common so as to refine and develop new treatments.

It might be difficult to recall at a time when concerns about data privacy have never been more heightened, but 10 years ago, big data was being talked about as the panacea to a range of social ills. Like nudge theory, its potential was unquestionably overhyped, but there is no doubt that in relation to healthcare, our personal data has not just life-changing but lifesaving potential. Observational data from the real world has paved the way for huge medical breakthroughs over the years, including establishing the links between thalidomide and birth defects and between smoking and cancer.

But the power of patient data remains cripplingly under-harnessed as a result of privacy concerns. Five years ago, NHS England announced it would be setting up a single, opt-out database - care.data - bringing together millions of patient records. The data would be made available in "pseudonymised" form (with personal information such as name and address removed) to medical researchers in the public and private sectors.

There are, however, privacy risks to such an undertaking that can't be eliminated. Even when data is pseudonymised, there's a small risk people can be identified if the information were matched with data from other datasets, for example those held by insurance companies. The public accounts committee said that last year's NHS ransomware attack was made possible by a lack of investment in cybersecurity - which doesn't inspire confidence.

The NHS sent every household a leaflet to explain the endeavour that "raised more questions than it answered", according to the   independent health data guardian. It certainly wasn't clear about what sort of safeguards might be adopted to ensure patient data would not get into the wrong hands.

So the resulting public outcry was perhaps inevitable and resulted in the whole thing being scrapped a couple of years ago. The tragic price? Potential delays to medical advances that could help us find new cures for diseases such as dementia and cancer.

Today, we are awash with examples of how our personal data could potentially be put to malign use. Insurers would love to get their hands on our health data so they can charge us premiums based on how likely we are to become ill. A social media giant such as Facebook is able to use the massive amounts of data it holds on us, including our likes, our private messages and our reading habits, to try to predict how we will react to commercial and political advertising and push us targeted marketing accordingly - a capability its developers are continuously honing.

And companies can use data to evade regulation and help them to break the law. The New York Times last year revealed how Uber had been using passenger data to systematically deceive local law enforcement officials.

Too often, data experts throw up their hands at the way in which we apparently undervalue the privacy of our personal data. The saga over care.data shows us how far from the truth this is: people can get very animated about the privacy of our data when we don't trust the people charged with keeping it safe and the benefits are either poorly explained or feel obtuse or too far into the future.

But there is a tragic asymmetry in our response to care.data and to the big tech companies.

Revelations about the reams of personal data that Facebook and Google hold about us, including which events in your calendar you actually attended and which apps you use and when, haven't resulted in masses of people closing their accounts. We seem to be less anguished about under-regulated, global tech giants holding deeply personal information about us than an arm's-length NHS body.

That asymmetry isn't surprising - it's just yet another product of our irrationality. We trade away our data for short-term benefits such as the convenience of an app, but the risks make us more reluctant to hand it over in service of long-term collective benefits such as improved medical care and new cures for diseases.

If we are to beat diseases such as cancer and dementia, that irrationality is something we need to overcome. Tessa Jowell has taken the first step. Hopefully some of us will follow. Perhaps in 10 years' time, we'll see people running races and baking cakes asking not just for cash sponsorship - but for friends and family to donate their health data.

· Sonia Sodha is an Observer columnist.

urn:contentItem:4G00-WXD0-01J8-W3WC-00000-00Medical Software Field Seeking Out Standards Fragmented industry rife with computer systems that can't communicate2005-04-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisSECTION INDUSTRY SNAPSHOT; KEY TRENDS; NATIONAL EDITION; Pg. A20Medical Software Field Seeking Out Standards Fragmented industry rife with computer systems that can't communicateBY KEN SPENCER BROWN

A raft of information technology promises to transform every aspect of the health care system.

Electronic records will make it easier to gauge a patient's medical history. Digital scans will give better looks inside the human body.

And computer prescriptions will cut transcription errors and bad drug combos.

That leaves one unsolved problem: tying everything together.

"The biggest issue in health care technology is connectivity," said Quovadx Chief Executive Harvey Wagner. His company, which sells integration services among other offerings, deals with the issue every day.

Few health care systems are designed to be compatible. That's no surprise, perhaps, since the U.S. health care industry itself is highly fragmented.

A single procedure can involve doctors, hospitals, insurers and the government -- all using different systems.

Lots of companies focus on niche areas of health care and small sets of customers. That's why your doctor's billing system won't always speak the same language as the one used by your insurer.

That creates overhead, says Sami Aita, CEO for medical software maker MedcomSoft. Care takes longer, and doctors often have to redo costly tests.

As the medical field puts more of its records on computers, it's critical to make sure data can flow smoothly, Aita says.

"The exchange of clinical information between different system is going to be the key to (electronic records)," he said.

But health care's scattered nature means there's no single body in charge of forging such standards.

"Easier said than done," said Datamonitor researcher Jocelyn Young. "A lot of work lies ahead."

Take the building block of medical data: the patient record.

Lost In Translation

Descriptions of basic medical procedures can vary from doctor to doctor. It gets more complex when adding hospitals and insurers to the mix.

Even when the terminology is the same, how do doctors translate those terms into data a machine can understand?

One proposed standard is Medcin, created in 1978 by Medicomp Systems. The proprietary standard includes a common set of terms to describe symptoms and treatments.

Medcin's database makes it easier to diagnose patients and document their treatment. With the right software, doctors can quickly match symptoms to other factors and treatments.

The cough of a 3-month-old baby, for instance, won't be treated the same as that of a 70-year-old smoker.

Backers of Medcin say the standard has become more useful as outside companies license it for their software.

Some hope Medcin becomes a free, open standard that software makers won't have to license.

Other Standards

If Medcin prevails, it'll have to work with a mix of other standards to reach its full promise.

In 2003, the Health and Human Services Department endorsed another standard called Snomed, or Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine.

Maintained by the College of American Pathologists, the system was already in use by the U.K. health system to track disease, clinical findings, therapies, procedures and outcomes.

The U.S. government licenses the standard to give health care open access to it.

The World Health Organization uses another standard called IDC, short for the International Classification of Diseases. (Medcin includes IDC info.)

The FDA wants to use another standard called MedDRA, or Medical Dictionary for Regulatory Activities.

The European Union and Japan already mandate its use.

An effort called Continuity of Care Record program hopes to bring many of these standards together.

It's sponsored by several groups, including the American Medical Association.

The idea is to create a health care-focused version of XML, the lingua franca of data exchange on the Web.

If it works, doctors will easily transfer patient info to other software, even Microsoft Word or Adobe Acrobat.

It's a grand idea. But there's little consensus on how to structure it.

The government, through Medicare, can throw some weight around, says Datamonitor's Young.

The private sector also will have to rally around these standards. Big tech firms like IBM, Oracle and Microsoft can play a role.

Ultimately, the strongest carrot will be the huge potential savings for the health care industry.

"At the end of the day, what gets reimbursed is what drives the industry," said Datamonitor's Young.

urn:contentItem:48M2-8680-01J8-W4J4-00000-00MEDICAL TRENDS Drug Makers Eye Cure For Long R&D Process2003-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisSECTION THE NEW AMERICA; NATIONAL EDITION; Pg. A05MEDICAL TRENDS Drug Makers Eye Cure For Long R&D ProcessBY GLORIA LAU

After riding blockbuster drugs to steady financial gains during the 1990s, many leading drug companies are coping with a sparse pipeline of new medicines.

Without new blockbusters, drug makers suffer from slow earnings growth. Just look at Merck & Co., one of the biggest and most respected drug makers on Wall Street.

Through most of the 1990s it enjoyed double-digit earnings growth. But last year, that growth came to a halt as its pipeline of new blockbusters shriveled up.

Late last month, Merck reported drug sales growth of 16% during the first quarter but flat profit in its core drug business.

The reason? Analysts say Merck is throwing money at scientists to boost their chances of finding new, big-selling drugs. It raised research and development spending for the quarter by 36% to $720 million.

"Crisis Period'

Rising R&D costs are a problem throughout the industry. A 2001 study by Tufts University found that it costs $802 million to develop one new prescription drug, up from $231 million a decade earlier.

But the number of new compounds winning regulatory approval is on the decline.

"The pharmaceutical industry is approaching a period of real crisis," said Caroline Kovac, general manager of IBM Corp.'s Life Sciences unit. "(There's) a productivity gap in the . . . business model."

IBM is one of several big tech firms touting software packages they say will speed up drug research.

One of IBM's software packages, DiscoveryLink, has already proved effective in shortening the process, Kovac says.

She claims it helped drug giant Aventis AG cut the time needed for early stage drug discovery to two months from the usual two to three years.

That's not just a sales pitch. Another fan of the product is Aventis Vice President Peter Loupos, who's in charge of finding ways to shorten the time it takes to discover a drug and get it approved by regulators for sale.

He says IBM's software has made it easier for scientists to dig through endless piles of data.

In November, an Aventis scientist discovered a new drug that might one day become a treatment for central nervous system, brain and spine diseases.

Loupos wouldn't discuss the new drug in detail. But he says without DiscoveryLink, the scientist might have overlooked the new compound entirely.

In the old days, scientists mixed compounds and chemicals in test tubes by hand. Back then, Aventis scientists produced 1,000 test results a year.

Today, much of the work is done by robots and computers, and Aventis generates some 40 million test results a year in its biological screenings of compounds.

"As the ability to generate data gets better, the challenge of capturing the data, managing it, integrating it and providing it to scientists becomes more and more complex," Loupos said.

Making The Connection

There are two solutions to the data managment problem, each favored by different drug makers. One is to put all the data in an electronic warehouse as they become available, then sift through them for useful nuggets.

Aventis prefers a different option, what it calls the "federated" approach.

The company leaves all of its data in each of its four labs and uses the DiscoveryLink to connect them.

DiscoveryLink works like the Google search engine. The difference is, it doesn't just find documents with the exact words you type. It also logically sorts through all related research and data before presenting the most relevant ones.

Loupos' goal is to reduce the time it takes to take a drug from discovery to the Food and Drug Administration.

The process currently takes more than a decade. He wants to cut it to six to nine years. He's counting on DiscoveryLink to help him do it.

"Now we can at least visualize the information (in a logical way)," Loupos said. "Before, this was never possible."

Paying Off

The DiscoveryLink system doesn't come cheap. Aventis spent $2 million on it, Loupos says. But, he adds, it's already begun to produce results.

"We already see workflow efficiencies in research," he said. "The (drug discovered in November) is now being studied for its chemical activities. Next year it goes into animal testing. If that drug ever comes to market and becomes a blockbuster, that's certainly the best metric (of success) I can think of."

Still, it's early in the program, and there's no proof any blockbusters will materialize.

Even if one doesn't, it's a safe bet that software designed to streamline the drug development process will only grow more popular.

Industrywide, sales of life sciences software grow at 18% a year in the U.S.. That's roughly double the growth rates for software products used in industries such as finance, banking, retail, distribution and manufacturing.

"With the use of high throughput (drug) screening and the genomics revolution, labs are generating lots of data -- more than the scientist can understand and use," said analyst Michael Swenson of technology research group IDC. "There's a greater reliance on computing."

IBM's life sciences unit is one of its fastest-growing segments of its overall business, Kovac says.

urn:contentItem:5XJS-T6H1-F03R-N3NG-00000-00Medill News Service: Tech giants Google, Amazon and Facebook accused of posing threat to small business2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisMedill News Service: Tech giants Google, Amazon and Facebook accused of posing threat to small businessfpwire

Nov 16, 2019( Financial Press: https://financialpress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Amazon, Google and other tech giants have been accused of undermining small businesses.WASHINGTON — Tech giants Amazon, Google and Facebook are facing increasing scrutiny from Congress over their online dominance and potential to threaten thousands of small businesses that compete with them. The criticism has ramped up over the past year, especially after Democrats regained control of the U.S. House of Representatives. Many lawmakers worry the concentration of power in the hands of just a handful of large companies could damage the ecosystem of the economy.

'The sheer size of these 'Big Tech' companies and their concentration of power influencing online traffic raises questions that should concern anyone who cares about market access and small business development,' Rep. Nydia Velazquez of New York said Thursday. 'There is growing anxiety, not only in the U.S. but around the world, that Big Tech poses a threat to innovation and competition,' she said. Velazquez made her remarks during a hearing Thursday by the House Small Business Committee to explore the influence of large tech companies. Velazquez, the panel's chairwoman, questioned the extent to which Big Tech is responsible for the 50% drop in the rate at which small businesses are started compared to 50 years ago. The hearing was part of a wider congressional and federal examination of Big Tech. Their almost exclusive ability to direct online traffic has raised major concerns about their influence on the survival and development of small businesses. The House Antitrust Subcommittee, for its part, has held hearings and requested documents from the tech companies about potentially anti-competitive practices. The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department also have opened inquiries into whether the big tech firms have violated antitrust law. Earlier this week, House lawmakers called for two top antitrust regulators to take more action against large tech companies, accusing them of swallowing up competitors and consolidating power for years whilst avoiding serious scrutiny. At Thursday's hearing, Amazon and Google executives defended their companies, saying they play a pivotal role in helping small businesses to reach more consumers. 'By offering small businesses a low-cost way to reach customers worldwide, and through our investments to support these businesses, Amazon lowers barriers to entry for entrepreneurs,' said Dharmesh Mehta, the company's vice president of customer trust and partner support. More than 50,000 small and medium sized businesses exceeded $500,000 in sales on Amazon in 2018, according to an Amazon AMZN, -0.86%[1] report. Yet critics say Amazon sometimes modifies product-search results and even decides to sell or manufacture products itself, posing a substantial harm to small businesses. Lawmakers have called on the company to show more transparency and fairness in the way it interacts with businesses and customers. Like Amazon, Google GOOG, 1.79%[2] also contends its online tools have helped small businesses to flourish. Erica Swanson, head of community engagement for its business-training Grow with Google initiative, defended Google's relationship with smaller firms. 'In 2018, Google's search and advertising tools helped provide $335 billion of economic activity nationwide' and 'more than 1.3 million businesses, website publishers, and nonprofits benefited' from the company's ad services, Swanson said. Those arguments did not appear to sway key lawmakers such as Velazquez. She said small businesses are at risk when they have to compete with large companies like Amazon and Walmart WMT, -1.48%[3], which spend millions on advertising in order to appear on the first Google search page. This 'crowds the opportunity for small businesses to advertise online,' Velazquez said. 'Small businesses cannot survive on the internet if they cannot be found.' Facebook FB, 1.01%[4] and Apple AAPL, 1.19%[5] were asked to testify but declined to do so. 'Their failure to appear not only impedes Congress' mission, but also speaks volumes about the companies' commitment to transparency and their very own customers,' Velazquez said.The post Medill News Service: Tech giants Google, Amazon and Facebook accused of posing threat to small business[6] appeared first on Financial Press - Breaking Stock Market News[7]. [ 1]: http://feeds.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/amzn [ 2]:   http://feeds.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/goog [ 3]:   http://feeds.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/wmt [ 4]:   http://feeds.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/fb [ 5]:   http://feeds.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/aapl [ 6]:   https://financialpress.com/2019/11/medill-news-service-tech-giants-google-amazon-and-facebook-accused-of-posing-threat-to-small-business/ [ 7]:   https://financialpress.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XJ4-8T71-JB5M-W2SN-00000-00Medium can't kill the message2019-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:22ZLexisNexisMedium can't kill the messageruchi gupta

The central problem at the heart of all electoral politics is the challenge of mass communication. Social media offers the ability to communicate with the masses with a hitherto impossible specificity. This has thrown up hotly-contested issues, especially after Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election.

One issue is the organised dissemination of misinformation, either as "fake news" or as paid political ads with false information. While there is consensus on the need for action against fake news, there is an interesting divergence on political ads. Facebook has carved out an exception for paid political ads from its fact-checking programme on the grounds that it is not the role of Facebook to adjudicate political speech in a democracy. On the other hand, Twitter has declared that it will stop all political advertising arguing that "political message reach should be earned, not bought". Twitter's stand may seem like it has the moral high ground but some concerns bear discussion.

The position of the two companies neatly sets up the policy framework and the choices therein: To carry political ads or not; to regulate political ads or not. Banning political ads will increase barriers to entry for smaller/newer entities, who require support to cross the initial threshold for visibility. Paid targeted advertising offers a cost-effective way to jump over this primary barrier and its banning will hurt new entrants. Well-funded and organised political entities will simply substitute paid advertising through employees and influencers to increase their reach.

Moreover, what is or isn't political is subjective. Consumer companies are increasingly making political pitches as a marketing tactic: A clothing company advertising that it pays fair wages; a company promising not to outsource jobs; big tech companies promising to invest in local housing; newspapers promising to report the truth. Are these ads political or apolitical? If we restrict "political" to only those ads aimed at public office, then how would we view the response of various companies to Donald Trump's immigration ban? A citizens' group mobilising for a candidate? How will we distinguish between candidates and proxies? Twitter may have decided that the conflict associated with political ads is not worth the trouble but the determination of what is political is itself conflicted.

If banning political ads is not possible, then some argue that political ads be fact-checked to ensure that voters are not fed targeted misinformation. This is reasonable. However, we may end up ceding democratic space to private companies. Political rhetoric often relies on exaggeration and spin. When spin and/or exaggeration shades into falsehood, it is personal and cannot be supplanted, wholesale, by private companies. In a polarised environment, private adjudication is likely to be arbitrary or seen to be so and it is certain every ruling will be challenged irrespective of merit. The logic of fact-checking if extended to other mass media will quickly get out of hand. Would a television or radio station carrying a live political speech be expected to stop transmission the moment a falsehood is uttered?

The real issue with online political ads is the ability to deliver (mis)information to targeted groups allowing the political entity to escape public scrutiny. A political party could conceivably target Dalits promising them social justice while simultaneously mobilising upper caste Hindus against reservations. If politics is ultimately about the collective and commons, then an argument against micro-targeting could be made. However, governance by definition encompasses multiple issues and it is difficult to argue that voters with different concerns be fed the same message. Perhaps a viable way forward could be transparency on all political ads along with associated targeting. This would expose hypocrisy and allow the Opposition to counter politically, as expected in a democracy. Other measures include clear labelling of political ads and spending caps to ensure that the smaller guys are not drowned by opposition content.

The rise of right-wing populism and the organised use of misinformation are political problems. A technological solution will necessarily be rule-based or algorithm-based and it is difficult to see how that could possibly address the essentially dynamic nature of politics. While some regulation is indeed desirable, it is important to ensure that we do not cede control over our democratic processes to private platforms.

Gupta is AICC joint secretary in charge of Congress' Student Wing. Views are personal

Banning political ads on social media is a technological solution to a political problem

The writer is AICC joint secretary in charge of the student wing of the Congress. She tweets @guptar

The central problem at the heart of all electoral politics is the challenge of mass communication. Social media offers the ability to communicate with the masses with a hitherto impossible specificity. A citizens' group mobilising for a candidate? How will we distinguish between candidates and proxies? Twitter may have decided that the conflict associated with political ads is not worth the trouble but the determination of what is political is itself conflicted.

If banning political ads is not possible, then some argue that political ads be fact-checked to ensure that voters are not fed targeted misinformation. This is reasonable. However, we may end up ceding democratic space to private companies. Political rhetoric often relies on exaggeration and spin. When spin and/or exaggeration shades into falsehood, it is personal and cannot be supplanted, wholesale, by private companies. In a polarised environment, private adjudication is likely to be arbitrary or seen to be so and it is certain every ruling will be challenged irrespective of merit. The logic of fact-checking if extended to other mass media will quickly get out of hand. Would a television or radio station carrying a live political speech be expected to stop transmission the moment a falsehood is uttered?

The real issue with online political ads is the ability to deliver (mis)information to targeted groups allowing the political entity to escape public scrutiny. A political party could conceivably target Dalits promising them social justice while simultaneously mobilising upper caste Hindus against reservations. If politics is ultimately about the collective and commons, then an argument against micro-targeting could be made. However, governance by definition encompasses multiple issues and it is difficult to argue that voters with different concerns be fed the same message. Perhaps a viable way forward could be transparency on all political ads along with associated targeting. This would expose hypocrisy and allow the Opposition to counter politically, as expected in a democracy. Other measures include clear labelling of political ads and spending caps to ensure that the smaller guys are not drowned by opposition content.

The rise of right-wing populism and the organised use of misinformation are political problems. A technological solution will necessarily be rule-based or algorithm-based and it is difficult to see how that could possibly address the essentially dynamic nature of politics. While some regulation is indeed desirable, it is important to ensure that we do not cede control over our democratic processes to private platforms.

Gupta is AICC joint secretary in charge of Congress' Student Wing. Views are personal
